tools: Two sets of Artisan's Tools of your choice

default: (a) Any two {@filter simple weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=simple weapon} of your choice.
(a) A {@item light crossbow} and {@item bolts|phb|20 bolts} or (b) a {@item rapier|phb|rapier}.
One set of Artisan's Tools of your choice.
Leather armor and a Scholar's Pack.

tools: An Artisan's Tools of your choice

entries: The slender elf cleans his glasses with the corner of his cloak as the dust settles around him. He was the first living thing to set foot in the ancient temple in hundreds of years. His benefactor had paid him a great deal to find this place, and after months of pouring over forgotten tomes he had finally figured out it's long-lost location. Now, he had a choice to make, would he report back to his benefactor allowing them to strip the temple of it's valuables? Or, would he keep the location hidden, and preserve the priceless information found here himself? To a Savant, knowledge is more precious than gold coins.

The elderly warrior assessed the state of his men, they were exhausted and almost out of supplies. This was the tenth day of the siege, and the warrior knew that at this point no reinforcements were coming to relieve them. He was too old to be of use in battle, but if his men followed his orders to the letter, and without hesitation, they just might have a fighting chance. He stood up, and for what could be the last time, drew his sword.

A young dwarf bends over his unconscious comrade in the midst of battle, his hands shaking as he examined the unconscious soldier's wounds. The elders of his clan had spent a great deal of their fortune to send him to the best university gold could buy. All those hours spent in lectures, libraries, and observation; all for this moment. He thought back to what he had learned about field medicine from his professors and began to dress the soldier's wounds.

entries.name: Great Minds
entries: There are many intelligent people in the world, but few are true Savants. Born with with an innate desire to learn all they can, and the potential for a genius level intellect, they spend their lives studying anything that those around them are willing to teach them. Savants are often recognized at an early age, and in their hunger for knowledge, they are drawn to great libraries, universities, and other places of higher learning. They will do anything to access the troves of knowledge that lie hidden in the forgotten places of the world, for Savants, no price is too steep to pay for a new discovery.

Despite their aptitude for learning, most Savants seek to better themselves without having to rely on outside influences. Savants reject the patronage of gods and other powerful beings, and in turn they view wizardry as a shortcut to power for the weak willed. Relying on their intellect alone, they strive for perfection.

entries.name: Intense Focus
entries: Savants tend to hyper-focus on their chosen area of expertise. They obsess over it, learning all they can about the subject. Once they reach the climax of learning in that specialty, and there is nothing anyone else can teach them, they do not move on. Instead they will go to great lengths, risking life and limb, to advance their chosen field of study.

Often doing so at great cost to themselves, Savants will not stop researching, experimenting, and theorizing until they have made an indelible mark on their academic discipline. A Savant's ultimate goal in life is to discover some previously unknown truth about the universe.

entries.name: Creating a Savant
entries: When creating your Savant consider their upbringing and level of formal education. Where they the star pupil of the kingdom's university? Or did they come from nothing, fighting for any scrap of knowledge they could get their hands on? Were they naturally intelligent, but unable to use their abilities because of obligations to family?

Whatever their origins, consider why they became an adventurer rather than an academic. Did they learn all they could from the dusty tomes in the library, and now they seek to discover forgotten temples and the knowledge within? Have they advanced beyond study and look to the endless discoveries of a life of adventure?

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a Savant quickly by following these suggestions. First, put your highest ability score in Intelligence, followed by Dexterity. Second, choose the Sage background from the Player's Handbook.

entries.name: Academic Disciplines
entries: A Savant's Academic Discipline is the focus of their considerable intellect and not a decision they make lightly. The following Academic Disciplines are available to a Savant; Archaeologist, Naturalist, Philosopher, Physician, or Tactician. Your Academic Discipline grants you features at 3rd, 7th, 13th, and 17th levels.

entries.name: Archaeologist
entries: Specializing in the study of ancient places, forgotten cities, and uncharted lands, Archaeologists boldly walk into the dark and deadly places of the world that they may be illuminated by the light of knowledge. Often funded by powerful politicians, universities, wizards, and other seekers of esoteric knowledge, this way of life has the potential for great profit, if you manage to survive.

Archaeologists do their best to piece together the lost knowledge of past ages. They tend to feel a sad kinship with the lost civilizations that they study, and will go to great lengths not to destroy or offend their memory. For an Archaeologist, learning from the innovations, and mistakes, of the past is the best way to improve the present and blaze a trail towards a better future.

entries.name: Naturalist
entries: The Naturalist's classroom begins at the very edges of civilization. They study the environments, flora, and fauna that live beyond the influence of civilized peoples. Naturalists are experts at anticipating weather patterns, knowing the difference between an edible plant and a toxic one, and understanding the behaviors of wild animals. Highly sought after as guides for adventuring parties, Naturalists can safely navigate arid deserts, frigid mountain ranges, and treacherous jungles.

entries.name: Physician
entries: From the dawn of civilization, mortals have studied the inner workings of living things. Clerics and priests of gods of life and healing, necromancers and despicable liches who seek to raise the dead, and lethal assassins and warriors who learn the most vulnerable points to strike. Unlike all of these, Physicians use their knowledge and mundane science to heal wounds, cure diseases, perform surgeries, and generally improve the quality of life for those that cannot afford the luxury of magical healing.

entries.name: Philosopher
entries: Philosophy is the purest of the Academic Disciplines that Savants pursue. Philosophers spend their lives pondering the deep questions of existence - What is the purpose of life? Why did the gods create the multiverse? What is the nature of the material plane and the planes that surround it?

Through their study of mathematics, physics, natural sciences, and public speaking, they seek to perfect their knowledge of reality and their place in it. Philosophers make invaluable advisors and thinkers when they are on your side. They range from humble village elders to imperial advisors.

entries.name: Tactician
entries: Every successful king, conquerer, or rebellion has a master strategist that is responsible for their success on the battlefield. Tacticians constantly work to stay one step ahead of their enemies, and have a plan prepared for every eventuality. They focus on the big picture, and while they may not win every battle, they strive to win the war.

You have spent your time studying the art of war and long forgotten histories of conquest and glory. You know the strategies that lead to victory, and those that end in ruin. Alone you are no threat, but with powerful allies to command, you are a force to be reckoned with.

classFeature.name: Adroit Analysis
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can make use of your lightning fast cognitive skills even as you engage in battle. As a bonus action on your turn, you can make an ability check with any skill or tool you are proficient in.

You can also use this ability to analyze the movement patterns and fighting style of an enemy creature. As a bonus action, choose a creature that you can see within 60 feet. The creature is marked by you, and whenever you make a weapon attack against the marked creature you can use Intelligence, in place of Strength or Dexterity, for the weapon attack and damage rolls.
The mark lasts for one minute, or until you fall unconscious. If you attempt to use this ability to mark another creature, the mark immediately ends for the first creature.

classFeature.name: Astute Defense
entries: Beginning at 1st level, your observant way of fighting allows you to predict enemy attacks with lightning fast accuracy. When you are not wearing any armor or using a shield your armor class is equal to 10 + your Dexterity modifier + your Intelligence modifier.

classFeature.name: Perfect Recall
entries: Your photographic memory allows you to remember even the most minute details. Starting at 1st level, if you spend at least one minute observing something you automatically succeed on any ability check to recall information about it.
Examples include things you've read, the appearances of people you've met, the layout of rooms, dungeons, or fortresses, speeches you've heard, and paths you've traveled.

classFeature.name: Expert Student
entries: When you reach 2nd level your appetite for knowledge allows you to learn at an accelerated rate. At the end of a short or long rest you can spend a few minutes to learn one additional language or gain one tool, skill, or weapon proficiency, as long as there is an example for you to learn from (like a teacher or manual). The proficiency or language lasts until you learn another proficiency or language with this feature.
Starting at 9th level you can have up to two additional languages or proficiencies at once using this ability.

entries.name: Appetite for Knowledge!
entries: Savants are the archetypal learner, desperate for knowledge of all kinds. Make sure to use your Expert Student ability to emphasize this aspect of your Savant. Learn local languages, practice skills, and learn to use new and exciting weapons!

classFeature.name: Iron Mind
entries: You have honed your mind into both a potent observational weapon and a stalwar shield against mental assaults. Starting at 2nd level, when you make an Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma ability check or a saving throw, you can use your reaction to grant yourself an additional bonus to the roll equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1). You use this feature after you roll, but before the Dungeon Master determines whether you succeed or fail.
You can use this ability a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once) and you regain all expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

classFeature.name: Academic Discipline
entries: At 3rd level, you choose your Academic Discipline. Choose between Archaeologist, Naturalist, Philosopher, Physician, or Tactician, each of which is detailed at the end of this class description. Your Academic Discipline grants you features at 3rd, 7th, 13th, and 17th levels.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

classFeature.name: Extra Attack
entries: Beginning at 5th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action on your turn.

classFeature.name: Expert Educator
entries: Beginning at 6th level you have become an expert at sharing your knowledge with others in a short amount of time. Choose one skill, tool, or weapon proficiency, or one language you know. At the end of a long rest, one creature of your choice that can hear you gains that proficiency or learns the language you selected. The benefits of this ability last until the end of your next long rest.
The proficiency or language you choose to teach with this ability can be one that you've acquired from Expert Student.
Beginning at 15th level this ability can effect up to three creatures at the end of a long rest, and you can teach each creature a different skill, tool, weapon, or language.

classFeature.name: Academic Discipline Feature
entries: At 7th level, you gain a feature granted by your Academic Discipline.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats. html}.

classFeature.name: Ever Vigilant
entries: When you reach 9th level your lightning fast observational abilities make it nearly impossible to catch you off guard. You have advantage on initiative rolls and you cannot be surprised while you are conscious.

classFeature.name: Potent Observation
entries: Starting at 10th level, when you mark an enemy creature with your Adroit Analysis, you can designate a number of creatures within 60 feet (including you) equal to your proficiency bonus. Once per turn, when a designated creature hits the marked creature with a weapon or spell attack, it deals 1d8 additional damage of the attack's type.
This effect lasts for one minute, until you fall unconscious, or you attempt to mark another enemy creature.
When you reach 15th level in this class the additional damage from this feature increases to 2d8.

classFeature.name: Reliable Talent
entries: You have mastered all known knowledge in your areas of study. Beginning at 11th level, whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats. html}.

classFeature.name: Academic Discipline Feature
entries: At 13th level, you gain a feature granted by your Academic Discipline.

classFeature.name: Mental Refresh
entries: Starting at 14th level you can use an action to clear your mind and automatically end one condition or spell effect currently affecting you. Once you use this ability you must complete a short or long rest before you can use it again.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats. html}.

classFeature.name: Academic Discipline Feature
entries: At 17th level, you gain a feature granted by your Academic Discipline.

classFeature.name: Profound Insight
entries: Beginning at 18th level, your almost supernatural ability to process the world around you allows you to predict your enemy's attacks as they happen. When an enemy creature is marked by Adroit Analysis they have disadvantage on any attack roll they make against you, and you have advantage on any saving throw they force you to make.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats. html}.

classFeature.name: Undisputed Genius
entries: Upon reaching 20th level, your intellect reaches its wondrous potential, far above the limits of all but the most intelligent beings. Both your Intelligence score, and maximum Intelligence score, increase by 6.

subclassFeature.name: Student of History
entries: Starting at 3rd level your study of bygone eras allows you unique insight into ancient and forgotten things. When you adopt this Academic Discipline you learn two exotic languages of your choice, and you gain proficiency in the History and Investigation skills, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with these proficiencies. If you are already proficient in History or Investigation you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the Savant skill list.

Additionally, your familiarity with civilization, both modern and ancient, allows you to glean additional types of information through observation. When you mark a creature with your Adroit Analysis you learn of any languages spoken by the creature and any special senses they may have.

subclassFeature.name: Daring Determination
entries: Ancient temples, forgotten cities, and hidden dungeons are deadly to most, but your time spent searching for secrets has honed your reflexes so you can better survive in such places. Starting at 3rd level you gain the following benefits:

items: When prone, it only costs you 5 feet of movement to stand.
When you hit a creature marked by Adroit Analysis with a melee attack, that creature cannot make opportunity attacks against you until the start of your next turn.

If you spend one minute examining an object, you can ascertain the monetary worth of the object, the civilization of origin of the object, and the approximate age of the object. If the item has any magical properties you discern them as if you had cast {@spell identify|PhB}.

subclassFeature.name: Relic Hunter
entries: Starting at 7th level, your familiarity with eldritch artifacts also allows you to operate them with ease. You can attune to a magic item at the end of a short rest, and you ignore all class, race, and level requirements on the use of magic items.
Additionally, you gain a bonus to your Dexterity saving throws equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Astute Offense
entries: You have learned to better defend yourself from the assaults of the denizens of the dark and forgotten places you explore. Beginning at 13th level, when you hit a creature marked by Adroit Analysis with a melee weapon attack you can force them to make a Constitution saving throw, in addition to the normal damage for the attack. The DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier.
On a failed save your strike cripples the creature, and it is Blinded, Deafened, or Restrained (your choice) until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Master Archaeologist
entries: Upon reaching 17th level your frequent exposure to magical effects has caused your body to develop a natural arcane ward. You are resistant to all magical damage, and have advantage on saving throws against magical effects.

subclassFeature.name: Student of Nature
entries: Beginning at 3rd level your choice to dedicate yourself to the study of natural world grants you a unique insight into the ways of the wild. When you adopt this Academic Discipline you gain proficiency in the Animal Handling and Nature skills, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with these proficiencies. If you are already proficient in Animal Handling or Nature you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the Savant skill list.

Additionally, your familiarity with creature types allows you to glean additional information through observation. When you mark a creature with your Adroit Analysis you learn its creature type and its highest and lowest ability scores.

subclassFeature.name: Conservationist
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your study of natural flora and fauna has given you insight into their weak points. Your weapon attacks that target a beast, monstrosity, or plant marked by Adroit Analysis score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

Additionally, at the end of a long rest, you can attune yourself to the natural environment you are currently in (examples include, but are not limited to, arctic, coast, desert, forest, grassland, jungle, mountain, swamp, or underdark). While in that environment you have advantage on any Intelligence or Wisdom ability checks you make related to native animals, plants, ecosystem or weather.

subclassFeature.name: Outdoorsman
entries: Upon reaching 7th level, you can use your knowledge of the wilderness to better guide your allies. At the end of a long rest you can prepare friendly creatures for upcoming dangers. You and a number of friendly creatures equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) gain one of the benefits listed below, which last until the end of your next long rest.
{@b Active Training}. Creatures ignore the effects difficult terrain imposed by natural environments and their base walking speed is increased by 10 feet.
{@b Concealment Training}. Creatures can move stealthily at a normal pace and can take the Hide action as a bonus action.
{@b Diver Training}. Creatures gain a swim speed equal to their move speed, and can hold their breath for a number of minutes equal to their Constitution score.

{@b Extreme Environment Training}. Creatures gain resistance to one of the following damage types (your choice); cold, fire, poison, or thunder damage, and have advantage on saving throws to resist the effects of extreme environments.
{@b Mountaineer Training}. Creatures gain a climb speed equal to their move speed and reduce any falling damage they take by an amount equal to your Savant level.

subclassFeature.name: Wild Insights
entries: You've come to understand the animals of the natural world in a way that few civilized peoples do. Starting at 13th level, as an action you can touch a beast or plant and attempt to charm it as if casting dominate beast. The save DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier. This ability can effect plants as well as beasts.
You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of once). You regain all uses when you finish a long rest.

subclassFeature.name: Master Naturalist
entries: You have become a leading authority on the natural world, and can maneuver with comfort in any natural environment you find yourself in. Starting at 17th level you automatically attune to your current environment for the purposes of your Conservationist ability, and you gain the benefits of all of your Outdoorsman features while you are conscious.

subclassFeature.name: Student of Thought
entries: Your time spent studying the fundamental nature of knowledge has provided you with great insights. When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level you gain proficiency in the Arcana and Religion skills, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make with these proficiencies. If you are already proficient in Arcana or Religion you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the Savant skill list.

Additionally, your time studying the nature of existence allows you to glean additional types of information through observation. When you mark a creature with Adroit Analysis you learn the creature's plane of origin, its spellcasting ability (if it has one), and the level of the highest spell it can cast.

subclassFeature.name: Resounding Theorems
entries: Starting at 3rd level, your mastery over the spoken word allows you to bolster your allies and sow confusion among your foes. As an action on your turn you can speak one of the following theorems aloud. Your words carry the very power of the multiverse, creatures do not need to understand your spoken language to be effected by your Theorems.
If one of your Theorems requires a creature to make a saving throw, the save DC is equal to 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier.

items: {@b Confounding Theorem}. You twist your speech to sow discord in the minds of your enemies. As an action, you can force a creature within 30 feet that can hear to you, to make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is Incapacitated until the start of your next turn.

{@b Inspiring Theorem}. You use your eloquence to bolster the resolve of your allies. As an action, choose one creature within 30 feet that can hear you. The creature can add 1d4 to all attack rolls or saving throws (your choice) they make until the start of your next turn.

{@b Melodic Theorem}. You spin honeyed words that disarm your foes. Creatures of your choice within 5 feet, that can hear you, must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save they are Charmed until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Unwavering Belief
entries: Beginning at 7th level, you have spent much time contemplating your existence and your place in the universe, and your confidence in your purpose is unwavering. You gain proficiency in Charisma saving throws.
In addition, when a creature marked by your Adroit Analysis fails the saving throw for one of your Theorems it takes psychic damage equal to 1d4 + your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Supreme Understanding
entries: Starting at 13th level, your understanding of the nature of reality allows you to bend it to your whims in minor, but poignant, ways. You gain the following Theorems.

items: {@b Sapping Theorem}. You use your mastery of language to weaken a creatures place in reality. As an action, you can force a creature within 30 feet that can hear to you, to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature suffers one level of exhaustion.

{@b Undermining Theorem}. You use your eloquence to temporarily shunt a creature from your current plane of existence. As an action, you can force a creature within 30 feet that can hear to you, to make a Charisma saving throw.

entries: On a failed save, the creature is temporarily shunted to the ethereal plane until the beginning of your next turn. While on the ethereal plane, the creature appears as a translucent, spectral, version of itself, and it cannot attack, cast spells, communicate, or interact with other creatures.

subclassFeature.name: Master Philosopher
entries: When you reach 17th level, your mastery over the language of the multiverse itself allows you to empower your Theorems with your very essence. When you use one of your Theorems, you can choose to impose disadvantage on the saving throw. If the creature succeeds on the saving throw, even with disadvantage, you immediately suffer one level of exhaustion.

subclassFeature.name: Student of Medicine
entries: When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level you gain proficiency with the Herbalism kit and in the Medicine skill. Medicine becomes an Intelligence skill for you, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any Medicine or Herbalism Kit ability check you make. If you are already proficient in Medicine or the Herbalism Kit you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the Savant skill list.

In addition, your time studying anatomy allows you to glean additional information through observation. When you mark a creature with Adroit Analysis, and any time you damage that creature with a melee attack, you learn the creature's hit point maximum and current hit points.

subclassFeature.name: Combat Medic
entries: Starting at 3rd level when you dedicate your life to the study of medicine you gain the following abilities. As an action on your turn you can use one of the following Medical Actions:

items: {@i Adrenaline Boost}. A creature you touch can use its reaction to repeat a saving throw to end one condition currently affecting it, adding your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) to the result of the roll.

{@i Crippling Strike}. You make a weapon attack against an enemy creature, targeting their physiological weak points. On hit, instead of dealing damage, the creature's movement speed is reduced to zero until the end of their next turn. If the creature is marked by your Adroit Analysis, your strike injures them in such a way that they are Restrained until the end of their next turn.
{@i Dress Wounds}. You bandage a creature's wounds, allowing them to fight on. A creature you touch gains temporary hit points equal to double your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

{@i Healing Surge}. Using your medicinal techniques you stimulate natural healing in a creature. A creature you touch can use its reaction to expend one of their hit dice. It immediately regains hit points equal to their hit die roll + their Constitution modifier + your Savant level. This ability does not effect unconscious or dead creatures.

{@i Stabilize}. You use your knowledge to stabilize a critically injured creature. You touch a living creature that has 0 hit points and the creature becomes stable. If you expend a charge of a healer's kit the creature regains hit points equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Medical Neutrality
entries: Beginning at 7th level you learn to move about the battlefield unscathed. If you use a Medical Action on your turn you also gain the benefits of the Dodge action.

subclassFeature.name: Field Surgeon
entries: When you reach 13th level your knowledge of medicine allows you to perform great feats of healing, on and off the battle field. You gain the following Medical Actions.

items: {@i Restorative Boost}. You touch a creature and can end one debilitating effect. You can reduce their exhaustion level by one, or end one condition effecting it. The condition can be Blinded, Charmed, Deafened, Paralyzed, Poisoned, a reduction to an ability score, or a reduction to their hit point maximum.
{@i Resuscitate}. Touch a creature that has died within the last minute. They are returned to life with one hit point as if you had cast revivify.

entries: Once you use either of these features you must complete a short or long rest before you can use either of them again.

subclassFeature.name: Master Physician
entries: Your knowledge of medicine and the inner workings of mortal bodies is peerless. Starting at 17th level, whenever you target a friendly creature with one of your Medical Actions they gain (additional) temporary hit points equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).
Additionally, any creature within 30 feet of you that spends hit dice at the end of a short rest, or as part of your Healing Surge ability, treat the hit dice as their maximum roll.

subclassFeature.name: Student of War
entries: When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level you dedicate yourself to the study of war and the skill necessary to lead others on the battlefield. You gain proficiency in the History skill, and your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make. If you are already proficient in History you gain proficiency with another skill of your choice from the Savant skill list.
You have also spent some of your time preparing to directly engage in battle. You gain proficiency with medium armor, shields, and all martial weapons that lack the heavy property.

Your time studying battle tactics allows you to glean additional types of information through observation. When you mark a creature with your Adroit Analysis you learn the creature's armor class and any resistances, immunities, or vulnerabilities they have.

subclassFeature.name: Tactical Commander
entries: When you adopt this Academic Discipline at 3rd level you learn to use your knowledge of battlefield tactics to empower your allies. You learn the following Orders that you can issue as an action on your turn.

items: {@b Attack Order}. Your command bolsters a creature's determination. Choose one creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you. The next time that creature takes the Attack action, before the beginning of your next turn, they can make one additional attack.

{@b Defensive Order}. Your words inspire creature's to protect themselves. As an action, choose one creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you. That creature gains a bonus to their armor class equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) until the beginning of your next turn.

{@b Rallying Order}. Your insights allow creatures to maneuver around the dangers of the battlefield. Choose one creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you. That creature can use their reaction to move up to their full movement speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

{@b Steadfast Order}. Your words inspire tenacity in your allies. Choose one creature within 30 feet that can see or hear you. That creature gain a bonus to all Strength and Constitution ability checks and saving throws equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1) that they make before the beginning of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Unwavering Resolve
entries: Your position as a leader does not afford you the comfort of succumbing to your base instincts. Beginning at 7th level, you are immune to the Frightened condition.
Additionally, when you use your action to issue an {@i Order} you can make one weapon attack as a bonus action on that turn.

subclassFeature.name: Strategic Genius
entries: Starting at 13th level, your experience as a commander on the field of battle allows you to strategically issue commands to multiple allies. When you use your action to issue an {@i Order}, you can issue one additional {@i Order} as part of the same action. Each {@i Order} must target a separate creature, as an individual creature can only follow one {@i Order} at a time.
Upon reaching 17th level you can issue up to three {@i Order} as part of the same action. Each Order must still target a separate creature.

subclassFeature.name: Master Tactician
entries: Your tactical mind ranks among the greatest military commanders of history, and your presence inspires heroic action in your allies. Starting at 17th level when you target a creature with an {@i Order} they gain temporary hit points equal to double your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1).
